moves.1. e4: This game was played terribly by me but it shows: never let your opponent get a queen in the endgame! e4 - Standard move.
moves.2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. e5 c5 5. a3 Bxc3+: a4, letting the Black Bishop out. However, most of Black's pieces are on the Queenside and White would be better attacking on that side.
moves.10... O-O 11. Bb2: Now the Bishop moves to b2. This cuts off its line of effect and although it lets the Q come to b1, Ba3 was probably better from that perspective.
moves.11... Nc6 12. Nd2 f6: f6, leaving a hole in the kingside, but trying to prevent a Kingside attack winning.
moves.13. exf6 Qxf6 14. Ba3: Now the Bishop moves to a3, probably what it should have done to start with.
moves.14... Rd8 15. Re1 Nce7 16. Bh5 b6 17. Re: Forcing the exchange, as the White Bishop was menacing on the Kingside.
moves.19. Bxg6 Qxg6 20. Rh3 Re8 21. Nf3 Bb7 22: b5?? I completely missed the threat!
moves.26... Kh8 27. Qxb7 Qb8: Now, I thought an attack would finish me off, so I sought to swap off Queens. My only other alternative was Qf6, which probably also swaps off after Qf7 (notice the N forks winning the Q if it is on g5 or d8)
moves.28. Qxb8 Raxb8 29. g4: g4! A good move by White. The Knight has no escape square, as Ne7 is punished by Bxe7, and if the Rook takes the Bishop, Ng6  winnning a whole rook.
g5, winning another pawn. White is playing this game well from two pieces for a pawn up.
moves.35... e5 36. gxh6 Rg6+ 37. Kf1 e4 38. hx: Now White swaps off material, which you should do when ahead.
moves.39... Rxg3 40. fxg3: Now White has two connected passed pawns, which should be enough to win...
moves.40... a5 41. Kg2 Kg6 42. Nb7 Ra8 43. h4: Black tries to push through the Queenside, as that is really his only hope.
moves.48... Re8 49. Re3 Rb8 50. Ba3 Rb1 51. Nd: Black now has to attempt to stop the pawn.
moves.55... Ra1: If White plays h6, then Rh1  wins the pawn.
moves.56. Kg4: White realises this and counters the threat again.
moves.56... Rh1 57. Kg5 Rf1 58. g4 Rf3: Now that the King is on g5, Black can try this line... Rxf3, exg3 and the pawn cannot be stopped, although both sides get Queens. I think this is a win for White however.
moves.59. Nc4: Nc4 - novel way of preventing the R taking!
moves.62. h7: It was probably wisest to get the B to a3, so it could stop the pawn.
moves.62... Rh3 63. Kg6 Kc6: Black realises that White's Rook can stop his pawn, so tries to get the king in.
moves.64. Kg7 Kd5 65. Re5+ Kc4 66. Rh5: Rh5! If RxR, gxR and after c2 the B can stop the pawn queening by going to a3.
moves.66... c2: c2! The only hope. It probably still loses.
moves.67. Rxh3 c1=Q 68. h8=Q Qg5+: Check until you can check no more!
moves.75... Qg6: neither does White! Black is threatening another spree starting at Qd3
moves.76. Kd2 Qc2+: Qc2 !! If the King takes, it is stalemate.

gameName: Don't let your opponent get a Queen!
